pros: Solid part-time, flexible role. Good structure for courses and students were largely wonderful.
cons: Lots of prep required and not much support. There were times when I could have used more guidance and didn't really get it. The sick policy was very murky. I was under the impression that if I missed class for any reason I would have to provide my own sub. As a result, I was showing up to class when I had severe strep throat bc I didn't know any other adjuncts.

review_title: They don't really care about their employees

cons: They don't care about their employees

pros: Friendly team and very flexible
cons: only a part time employee

review_title: It’s all good until it’s not
pros: Benefits, retirement, school schedule, student focused
cons: Lots of favoritism and equal opportunity instead of choosing the best person for the job

pros: Had a wonderful experience with the department head and fellow adjuncts during my time teaching at CCBC.
cons: The pay wasn't great, but people don't become educators for the pay. Wasn't a lot of opportunity for tenured positions.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Baltimore, MD
pros: Excellent atmosphere. Friendly/welcoming and thoughtful. Enjoy my role there. The students are excellent.
cons: As adjunct faculty, it is very difficult to see how I get paid and what I got paid for. Even though my schedule varies widely, they attach me to a class and I get paid for the number of hours I'm anticipated to work? It's unclear and not itemized in any way so I rarely know how much I will make in one paycheck or another. I have asked for clarification from payroll and am told this "has been an ongoing problem for adjunct faculty for years".

pros:
Competitive pay
Excellent health benefits
Possibility of promotion/growth
cons:
Women not treated as well as men
Incompetence 
Unethical behavior

pros: Friendly staff and autonomy with lesson planning, even as a first time professor
cons: None, it was a great place that treated adjuncts well.

review_title: Seriously consider (start as an adjunct to get your foot in the door)!
pros: The culture is great! Wonderful colleagues, lots of PD, advancement opportunities are accessible; work balance is well within grasp.
cons: The students are not the most focused or prepared which compounded by their lack of motivation and dedication. Some even feel entitled to passing grades even though they have not earned.

pros: well-supported by superiors and emphasis on instructional technology training
cons: limited course offerings so there are not always classes to teach

pros:
◦Learning and being trained on new systems
◦Challenging and Rewarding projects
◦Sent to professional conferences 
◦Wonderful department and co-workers with real sense of camaraderie
◦Professional Development Day on campus
◦Work Life Balance

HR benefits are awesome!! I'll repeat - they are incredibly awesome compared to the corporate world
◦Employee Tuition paid for any CCBC classes credit or non-credit
◦Employee Tuition reimbursement for other institutes
◦Tuition reimbursement for spouse and children if attending CCBC
◦7.5 hour work days
◦Excellent health benefits
◦Maryland State Retirement benefits

PTO:  
◦Holidays - 9 holidays plus Spring break & Winter break (19 days a yr)
◦Vacation - 20 days per year for Administrators and 12-month Faculty; 10 days per year for Classified Employees, with increases every 5 years to maximum of 20 days
◦Sick - 12 days first year, 18 days after 1+ years
◦3 days personal, 4 days family illness, 2 religious holidays

Staff & Staff/Family events throughout the year:
◦Free Italian Ice/Snow Balls for all employees one day each year
◦Free staff exercise classes offered at lunch time (aerobics & yoga)
◦Potluck luncheons
◦Bring Your Child to Work Day
◦Service Recognition Luncheon
◦Topping Off Ceremony for new bldgs on campus
◦Free lunch several days a year at events such as Fall Focus, Professional Development Day, Annual Meet & Greet, Holiday Open Houses, Teaching Learning Fair, Retirement Luncheons, Dept Luncheons, etc.
◦Free & Discounted tickets to Campus Concerts, Recitals, Theatre Productions, & Campus Observatory
◦Yearly Crab Feast & Yearly Five Star Gala 

Ten reasons why a university job is better than a corporate job:
1. Job Security
2. Gym
3. Library
4. Interesting and Rewarding Projects 
5. Tuition Discounts
6. Vacation / Time Off
7. Commitment to Standards 
8. Work Week Hours 
9. Health Insurance / Benefits
10. Campus Community
cons:
◦Less pay than in the corporate environment
◦Three weeks at beginning of Fall Semester and 2 weeks at beginning of Spring Semester that are "ALL HANDS" when no one can take time off

pros: I enjoyed working with the faculty and staff at the college. The workshops that are available for adjuncts were informative and provide opportunities for improving as an instructor. The promotion guidelines were clearly stated. The parking is free.
cons: One downside is the salary as compared to other colleges in the area.

pros: Friendly co-workers. Flexible schedule. Interesting work.
cons: There is a lack of communication from superiors.

pros: relaxed if you know what you are doing
cons: could have done better on salaries

pros:
They care about 2 things. Getting a bonus check and having there name put on something. Lack of training and knowledge on databases  and the fact that they think very little of its employees continue to be a problem as well.
The benefits are just ok and forget about retirement. Pay is on the low side and it's a pain to try to get equipment. Job  itself is not hard most days but don't expect to get any respect  as a professional. Too many managers pointing fingers at each other and not fixing key issues. They don't know what a developer does and administrator does poor management especially in Infrastructure team. They 
need to hire who have knowledge on databases especially they don't have knowledge on retention policy on  backups and how long backups  need to keep.
cons: HR  department is very  friendly.

pros: Good leadership in some areas; lots of pt job options; some schedule flexibility depending on dept; stayed bc schedule and location worked for my family needs
cons: Very disorganized place; focused on getting students in the door not on them completing; one initiative after another but they don't see anything through; too many long service entitled employees that pass the buck; no raise in 6 years bc I was pt; too much who you know rather than what you know when it comes to advancement; old boy network is alive and well

review_title: Great in many ways, but there are downsides, too ...
pros: Great salary for the field, great benefits, flexible schedule (usually). Most co-workers are collegial.
cons: Afraid to evaluate teacher effectiveness but willing to mandate teaching methods. Many roads lead to Rome! That is, there are many ways to be an effective teacher. Arriving in Rome should be the emphasis, not the route taken!

job_title: Public Safety Officer in Glenarden, MD
pros: The experience gathered from interaction with students , faulty and staff
cons: No forward progression could be more Than what it is sucks as a department from top to bottom . Hires mostly washed up leftovers from Baltimore city police who weren’t able to retire ... or left in a shaky matter. Brainwashes new recruit into thinking it’s more than what it is steer clear unless you’ve already put 20+ with another department and just looking for a supplement . Defiantly not a young mans job .

review_title: not as good as it could be
pros: Many of the coworkers are very good people with a lot to offer to the advancement of CCBC.
cons: Administration's management style is heavy handedly micro-management, about  everything and doesn't like to be second guessed.  In today's world you have to expect to be micro managed but at least have some experience about what you micro-manage, or depend on the experts you hired in the field expertise and knowledge.  Trust why you hired them or you become depended on yes guys who eliminate anyone they perceive as a threat by lies about them.  This is the ons with CCBC.

review_title: Decent, but has potential to be much better
pros: The campuses are easy to get to, I have friendly co-workers who are great to work with, and I like most of the work that I do.
cons: It feels like upper management/administration is rather disorganized and does not always listen to departments and what they need. There is at least one department that has been without a director or coordinator for years.

pros: Great students especially foreign born students studying English.  They are hard-working and very appreciative of their teachers' efforts on their parts.
cons: Poor administration of certain programs.  There is insufficient pre-admission testing and interviewing.  The testing mechanisms for placement in ESL classes needs to be revised and made to include a personal interview similar to the language OPI placement test.

review_title: Working in the Student Success Center is great.
pros: Friendly atmosphere with relatable peers. Hours are consistent from week to week unless a change is needed to accommodate someone asking off. Even so, you are never required to work the asked-for hours. Schedule is typically flexible if you need to ask for time off.
cons: Only allowed a maximum of 20 hours per week during the regular semesters, and less during shortened semesters (such as winter or summer). No benefits other than fairly flexible hours if you need time off.

job_title: Program Assistant in Owings Mills, MD
pros: I enjoyed working at the Community College of Baltimore County. It was nice to be in a college environment, I took classes and was reimbursed and the people I worked with were great. I enjoyed helping students and professors.
cons: Their was a hiring freeze and there were no raises for the five years I worked their. That was tough.

job_title: GED Proctor in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: I enjoy the convenience and flexibility of this position. I live within a 5 mile radius and am able to use Public Transportation if my car is in need of repairs.
cons: I would like to gain full time employment. This job is a part-time job and does not have enough hours to be a full time position

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Glen Burnie, MD
pros: Have a very supportive athletic community throughout the school. Athletic Director helps to the best of his knowledge for answers we might know know
cons: there are a lot of time and hours put into coaching all of the athletic teams and now getting paid enough hurts a little bit

review_title: Not all it's cracked up to be
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Dundalk, MD
pros: Easy job.  Paid college classes.
cons: No place to more up.  No real perks.  Pay is just ok. Benefits are lacking. Held back from doing your job fully.  Not even close to a real Police Department.  The college will lie to your face and smile.

job_title: Adjunct Professor/Academic Coach *Adjunct Faculty Member in Baltimore, MD
pros: Love the work environment, great pay.
cons: Inconsistent, very difficult to get full-time. Full-timers are in a fantastic position with excellent pay and benefits, but they seem to suppress the part-timers and keep them down.

pros: Pension plan, free tuition, opportunities for growth, paid vacation, sick leave, paid spring and winter break, cheap dental plan, great hours
cons: Insurance cost is sky high, pension plan is a mandatory ten percent pay deduction, human resources employees are rude, payroll constantly messed up or forgets to pay their part time employees

review_title: Nice Place but No Room for Advancement
pros: Nice people to work with, winter and spring breaks, good students
cons: Little to no room for professional growth, little to no diversity in management, work gets boring

pros: Flexible schedule, some decision in what you teach
cons: Antiquated mentality of 21st century workplace, incompetent and lazy deans and department chairs, good ole boy white men's club, seriously lack of diverse leadership

pros: Good pay, Excellent benefits, lovely campuses
cons: It's an organization stuck in old paradigms and provides little growth opportunity for POC.

review_title: My twenty plus years at this institution have been very fulfilling.
pros: Good leadership.  Open communication. Salaries and benefits.
cons: Too much red tape at times.

pros: CCBC is a great place to work and grow.  There are many locations with students and staff from the public and private sector.
cons: People tend to stay in one position for many years.

pros: Great environment and great pay. Lot's of activities and lunches and appreciation ceremonies for staff.
cons: Difficult to get a full-time position.

cons: Pay rate is low and part-time staff is not treated with the same level of respect as full-time.
